articles.headline: Truth Social Review: Trump’s Uncensored Social App Is Incomplete
articles.snippet: The Trump-backed social media app is inundated with phony accounts and features that don’t work. It also hides some posts, including those with curse words.
articles.abstract: The Trump-backed social media app is inundated with phony accounts and features that don’t work. It also hides some posts, including those with curse words.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Elon Musk sealed a deal to buy Twitter for $44 billion this week, another social networking product surged to No. 1 in Apple’s App Store: Truth Social, the flagship app of former President Donald J. Trump’s fledgling social media company.

articles.headline: Ukraine War Impact Widens: Russia Cuts Gas Flow and Vows More Reprisals
articles.snippet: New explosions across Ukraine’s borders, Russia’s shut-off of natural gas to two European nations and Moscow’s warning of additional “counterstrikes” pointed to escalating hostilities.
articles.abstract: New explosions across Ukraine’s borders, Russia’s shut-off of natural gas to two European nations and Moscow’s warning of additional “counterstrikes” pointed to escalating hostilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Reverberations from the Ukraine war widened on Wednesday, jolting energy markets and spilling across borders, as Russia responded to the West’s escalating arms shipments and economic penalties by halting gas supplies to two European nations and threatening further unspecified retaliation.
articles.byline: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Neil MacFarquhar, Shashank Bengali and Megan Specia

articles.headline: The Driver, the Officer and the Deadly Traffic Stop in Grand Rapids
articles.snippet: Patrick Lyoya’s path begins in central Africa, Christopher Schurr’s in Michigan. They cross on a rainy spring morning, in an encounter over a license plate. One ends with a bullet.
articles.abstract: Patrick Lyoya’s path begins in central Africa, Christopher Schurr’s in Michigan. They cross on a rainy spring morning, in an encounter over a license plate. One ends with a bullet.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Patrick Lyoya never quite found his footing. His family fled conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and he spent nearly half his life in a refugee camp in Malawi. He dreamed of coming to America, but after arriving here, he struggled to find his place, bouncing among homes, low-wage jobs and jail.
articles.byline: By Kim Barker, Steve Eder and Julie Tate

articles.headline: Fears Are Mounting That Ukraine War Will Spill Across Borders
articles.snippet: American and European officials say their concern is based in part on a growing conviction that the war will not end any time soon.
articles.abstract: American and European officials say their concern is based in part on a growing conviction that the war will not end any time soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For nine weeks, President Biden and the Western allies have emphasized the need to keep the war for Ukraine inside Ukraine.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Shrank in First Quarter, but Underlying Measures Were Solid
articles.snippet: The overall figure understates the recovery because inventories needed less rebuilding and consumer spending widened the trade deficit.
articles.abstract: The overall figure understates the recovery because inventories needed less rebuilding and consumer spending widened the trade deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy contracted in the first three months of the year, as supply constraints at home, demand shortfalls abroad and rapid inflation worldwide weighed on an otherwise resilient recovery.

articles.headline: A French Hit on Netflix Changes Its Language and Streaming Service
articles.snippet: “Call My Agent!,” set at a Parisian talent agency, was a cult favorite during the pandemic. But the English-language adaptation will be on Sundance Now and AMC+.
articles.abstract: “Call My Agent!,” set at a Parisian talent agency, was a cult favorite during the pandemic. But the English-language adaptation will be on Sundance Now and AMC+.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four bumbling talent agents at risk of losing their business because of poor financial planning. A secret daughter interested in a career in the entertainment industry. Cameos by famous actors playing themselves. One spoiled dog. This is the formula that made the French show “Call My Agent!,” about a Parisian talent agency, into a global hit once it began appearing on Netflix in 2016.

articles.headline: The Revolt of the College-Educated Working Class
articles.snippet: Since the Great Recession, the college-educated have taken more frontline jobs at companies like Starbucks and Amazon. Now they’re helping to unionize them.
articles.abstract: Since the Great Recession, the college-educated have taken more frontline jobs at companies like Starbucks and Amazon. Now they’re helping to unionize them.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Ramadan Nights Provide Cherished Pause in a Sudan on the Brink
articles.snippet: “We come here to forget it all,” one young musician said during the daily end of the fast. “The heat, the electricity cuts, the protests. Here, at least, we can sing.”
articles.abstract: “We come here to forget it all,” one young musician said during the daily end of the fast. “The heat, the electricity cuts, the protests. Here, at least, we can sing.”
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Friday night by the Nile, and a love song wafted on the warm breeze that blew across Tuti Island, a crescent of land at the confluence of the river’s two great branches.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Abdulmonam Eassa
